facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th January, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 107 of 1954 under the Chartered Accountants Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th January, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in exercise of its Special Jurisdiction under the Chartered Accountants Act, 1949, in Matter No. 107 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 10, 1957 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. September 10. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-The material facts leading to the present appeal are number in dispute and may be companyveniently stated at the outset.

facts.text: Respondent enrolled as registered accountant on July 17, 1933 under Auditors Certificate Rules, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts leading to the present appeal are number in dispute and may be companyveniently stated at the outset. On July 17, 1933, the respondent was enrolled as a registered accountant under the Auditors Certificate Rules, 1932.

facts.text: Respondent's name entered as Member of Institute of Chartered Accountants of India on July 1, 1949 when Chartered Accountants Act, 1949 came into operation.

anchor.surface_text: When the Chartered Accountants Act, 1949, came into, operation, the respondents name was entered as a Member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of lndia on July 1, 1949.

facts.text: Respondent appointed Liquidator of three companies on September 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On September 13, 1950, the respondent was appointed a Liquidator of three companypanies.

facts.text: Respondent obtained refund of sums and securities deposited on behalf of the three companies with Reserve Bank of India.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent obtained refund of the sums and securities deposited on behalf of the three companypanies with the Reserve Bank of India.

facts.text: Respondent made no report about progress of liquidation of the three companies.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, made numberreport about the progress of liquidation of the said three companypanies.

facts.text: Repeated requests by Assistant Controller of Insurance to respondent found no response.

anchor.surface_text: Repeated requests made to him by the Assistant Controller of Insurance found numberresponse.

facts.text: Respondent gave cheque to Shri S. K. Mandal towards payment of taxed costs in winding-up of one company, which was returned dishonoured.

anchor.surface_text: As Liquidator the respondent gave a cheque to Shri S. K. Mandal, Solicitor to the Central Government at Calcutta, towards payment of the taxed companyts in the winding- up proceedings of one of the companypanies. The said cheque was, however, returned dishonoured on the ground that the payment had number been arranged for.

facts.text: Assistant Controller of Insurance cancelled respondent's appointment as Liquidator by letter dated October 29, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: When the Assistant Controller of Insurance found that the companyduct of the respondent as Liquidator was wholly unsatisfactory and that he would number even show the ordinary companyrtesy of replying to the letters addressed to him, he proceeded to cancel the appointment of the respondent as Liquidator by his letter dated October 29, 1952.

facts.text: Respondent called upon to hand over books, records, documents to Shri N. N. Das appointed in his place.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was then called upon to hand over all books of account, records, documents, etc., to Shri N. N. Das, who was appointed a Liquidator in his place.

facts.text: Shri Das and Assistant Controller made repeated demands on respondent to deliver assets and records.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Das as well as the Assistant Controller of Insurance then made repeated demands on the respondent to deliver to Shri Das the assets and records of the three companypanies.

facts.text: Respondent had securities of Rs. 11,950 and cash Rs. 642 on account of United Common Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the respondent had with him securities of the value of Rs. 11,950 and a cash sum of Rs. 642 on account of the United Common Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Respondent had securities of Rs. 12,100 on account of Asiatic Provident Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: He had also with him securities to the value of Rs. 12,100 on account of the -Asiatic Provident Co. Ltd.,

facts.text: Respondent had securities and cash on account of Citizens of India Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: and securities and cash on account of the Citizens of India Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Respondent returned securities of face value Rs. 10,000 of Asiatic Provident Co. Ltd. and Rs. 350 of United Common Provident Insurance Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these amounts the respondent returned only securities of the face value of Rs. 10,000 and Rs. 350 of Asiatic Provident Co. Ltd., and United Common Provident Insurance Co. Ltd., respectively.

facts.text: Respondent failed to send further securities or cash for the three companies.

anchor.surface_text: He failed to send any further securities or cash held by him on account of the said three companypanies.

facts.text: Complaint lodged against respondent with Council of Institute of Chartered Accountants of India in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: It was at this stage that a companyplaint was lodged against the respondent with the Council of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India in Calcutta.

facts.text: Disciplinary committee inquired into the matter as per Act; notice served but no written statement filed by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: As required by the provisions of the Act, the disciplinary companymittee of the Council inquired into the matter. Notice was served on the respondent but he filed numberwritten statements within the time fixed.

facts.text: On August 1, 1953, respondent wrote he was ill, unable to attend, requested adjournment.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1953, a letter was received from the respondent that he was ill and was unable to attend personally. The respondent had also requested for the adjournment of the case.

facts.text: Proceedings adjourned to August 29, 1953; respondent represented by counsel who filed affidavit stating prepared to hand over cash, books without accounts.

anchor.surface_text: Proceedings were accordingly adjourned to August 29, 1953, on which date the respondent was represented by a companynsel who filed the respondents affidavit stating that he was prepared to hand over the entire cash, books of account, etc., to the newly appointed Liquidator without rendering the necessary accounts.

facts.text: Shri Das gave evidence before disciplinary committee.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Shri Das, the subsequently appointed Liquidator, gave evidence before the disciplinary companymittee.

facts.text: Respondent failed to appear or participate despite opportunities.

anchor.surface_text: Though several opportunities were given to the respondent to appear before the disciplinary companymittee he failed to appear or to take part in the proceedings.

facts.text: Disciplinary committee report on September 13, 1953 found respondent guilty of gross negligence in conduct of professional duty.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately the companymittee made its report on September 13, 1953, and found that the respondent was guilty of gross negligence in the companyduct of his professional duty in number handing over charge of the assets and the books of account of the said companypanies to the newly appointed Liquidator.

facts.text: Council agreed with finding but viewed acts and omissions as more serious than gross negligence.

anchor.surface_text: This report was companysidered by the Council itself as required by the Act. Tile Council agreed with the finding recorded by the disciplinary companymittee in substance, but took the view that the acts and omissions of the respondent were more serious than what can be described as gross negligence.

facts.text: Council's finding forwarded to Calcutta High Court under section 21(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the Council was then forwarded to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta as required by section 21  1  of the Act

facts.text: Calcutta High Court (Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Lahiri) by judgment January 12, 1955 rejected the reference.

anchor.surface_text: and the matter was heard by the learned Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Lahiri. By their judgment delivered on January 12, 1955, the reference was rejected on the ground that numberaction companyld be taken against the respondent under the Act

facts.text: Material facts leading to the appeal are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts leading to the present appeal are number in dispute and may be companyveniently stated at the outset.

issues.text: what is the nature, scope and extent of the disciplinary jurisdiction which can be exercised under the provisions of this Act against the respondent

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the main point which arises for our decision is what is the nature, scope and extent of the disciplinary jurisdiction which can be exercised under the provisions of this Act against the respondent.

arguments.claim: Conduct as liquidator deemed 'in practice' under s.2(2)(iv) via Reg.78; thus professional misconduct

anchor.surface_text: Let us first consider whether the conduct of the respondent amounts to professional misconduct or not. In dealing with this question it is necessary to bear in mind the provisions of s. 2, sub-s.  2   iv  of the Act. A member of the Institute under this provision shall be deemed to be in practice when he renders such other services as in the opinion of the Council are or may be rendered by a chartered accountant.

arguments.claim: s.22 inclusive definition; does not limit s.21 powers to inquire into conduct rendering unfit

anchor.surface_text: Section 22 purports to define the expression companyduct which, if proved, will render a person unfit to be a member of the Institute. It is an inclusive definition it includes any act or omission specified in the schedule but the latter portion of s. 22 clearly lays down that numberhing companytained in this section shall be companystrued to limit or abridge in any way the power companyferred on the Council under sub-s.  1  of section 21

anchor.surface_text: The companyduct of the respondent is, in our opinion, wholl- yunworthy of a chartered accountant in practice. His refusal to give prompt replies to the letters received from the Assistant Controller of Insurance followed by his failure to return the documents and all securities and cash received by him as liquidator leave numberroom for doubt that he was unable to return the said amount and the said securities and cash and that he was merely employing delaying tactics with the object of postponing the evil day.

precedents.cited_proposition: falsity of statement by chartered accountant while giving evidence as a witness (not as chartered accountant) does not give rise to disciplinary proceedings against him as chartered accountant
precedents.cited_holding: when a chartered accountant gives evidence before a court of law and he is in the witness box not as a chartered accountant but as a witness, the falsity of his statement does not give rise to any disciplinary proceedings against him as a chartered accountant

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ashwini Kumar Ghosh, for the respondent, has also sought to rely on Haseldine v. Hosken 1 . In this case the solicitor had taken out an indemnity policy which insured him against loss arising by reason of any neglect, omission or error while acting in his. professional capacity.

precedents.cited_proposition: loss arising from entering into a champertous agreement is not by reason of neglect, omission or error in professional capacity but from personal speculation
precedents.cited_holding: the loss in respect of which indemnity was claimed did not arise by reason of any neglect, omission or error committed by the solicitor in his professional capacity but arose from his entering into a personal speculation

Professional misconduct concept supports holding of clear guilt.
The extension of 'in practice' to liquidators brings related conduct within the disciplinary ambit, supporting the holding that the respondent is guilty of professional misconduct.

The concept of artificially extending 'in practice' to include liquidators via s.2(2)(iv) and Reg.78 provides the doctrinal basis (harmonious construction) for the holding that the respondent as liquidator is deemed to be in practice under s.2(2).
The harmonious construction extending 'in practice' addresses whether the respondent's conduct as liquidator amounts to professional misconduct by including it in the disciplinary ambit.
The concept of conduct rendering unfit defines the broader nature, scope, and extent of disciplinary jurisdiction raised in i1
The broader unfit conduct concept counters the narrow confinement to technical professional misconduct critiqued in i3
